name: Fort Laramie National Historic Site
description: Originally established as a private fur trading fort in 1834, Fort Laramie evolved into the largest and best-known military post on the Northern Plains before its abandonment in 1890. Nicknamed the “Grand Old Post,” Fort Laramie witnessed the entire sweeping saga of America’s western expansion and Indian resistance to encroachment on their territories.
shortDescription: Originally established as a private fur trading fort in 1834, Fort Laramie evolved into the largest and best-known military post on the Northern Plains before its abandonment in 1890. Nicknamed the “G...

operatingHours.description: The park grounds are open from dawn until dusk every day of the year. Some historic buildings may be closed in winter. Post trader store and cavalry barracks are open daily - weather permitting.

climate.weatherDescription: Fort Laramie summer days can be quite hot (over 100F/37C), average highs are in the 80s and 90s (30-35C) with cool nights and low humidity. Winters are often bitterly cold and windy with subzero wind chills. The region is semi-arid with a distinct winter dry season. About 70% of annual precipitation falls as thunderstorms during the spring and early summer. Breezy days are common year-round and peak in the winter when wind speeds can approach hurricane-strength.

images.title: Old Bedlam
images.altText: A large two story white building with pillars. Several windows with green shutters
images.caption: Oldest Building in the State of Wyoming.

images.title: Parade Ground from the Porch of "Old Bedlam"
images.altText: View of the parade ground from the porch of "Old Bedlam".
images.caption: A fall view of the parade ground from "Old Bedlam" the oldest surviving structure at Fort Laramie and in the state of Wyoming, constructed in 1849.

images.title: Post Trader at Work
images.altText: Living history interpreter portraying the Post Trader.
images.caption: In the summer living history interpreters bring the post to life, including the Post Trader in the refurnished 1849 store.

images.title: Fur Trade Fort Laramie Event
images.altText: Living history interpreter explaining the life of a trapper/trader to young visitors
images.caption: Special attention is given to helping our young visitors understand the past at Fort Laramie National Historic Site.

images.title: Arial View of Fort Laramie NHS From the South
images.altText: Aerial view of Fort Laramie NHS from the South
images.caption: Overview of Fort Laramie as it exists today with many of the historic buildings fully restored and refurnished and numerous other ruins and foundations.

images.title: Tipis Across Laramie River in Fall
images.altText: Two tipis across the Laramie River from the fort in fall
images.caption: Tipis were a common scene at Fort Laramie from 1834-1872.  At times, during treaty negotiations dozens of tipis could be found here.

images.title: Fall colors on the Parade Ground
images.altText: Ash and cottonwood trees show their fall colors next to an open grass field.
images.caption: Fall colors paint the parade grounds near Old Bedlam.

images.title: Powder Magazine in Winter
images.altText: Ruins of a concrete structure with snow on top.
images.caption: Ruins of the powder magazine within the winter snows.

images.title: Morning Fog at the Old Holtclaw Tract
images.altText: A deer looking up in morning fog near the shelter belt at the old Holtclaw Tract homestead.
images.caption: Morning fog north of Fort Laramie

images.title: 11th Kansas Ride Past the Cavalry Barracks
images.altText: A group of mounted individuals ride hors near a concrete historic structure.
images.caption: Riding past the Cavalry Barracks
